Applications for Fall Workshop Series

Ajay Perumbeti

Post-doc | Biomedical Informatics | aperumbe@arizona.edu

How comfortable are you with the following skills?

Navigate around filesystem using shell commands 3: Perform task with no help
Use git commands such as git add and git push 3: Perform task with no help
Share your code using a GitHub repo 3: Perform task with no help
Organize and name files/folders for a research project 3: Perform task with no help
Use R to clean and reformat dataframes 2: Perform task with some help
Write your own function in R 1: Not able to perform task
Use a for loop in R 2: Perform task with some help
Document text and code/output using RMarkdown 3: Perform task with no help

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

I am currently using it for Transcriptome analysis, and electronic health record analysis.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

I have found that I still struggle with data formatting errors when using analysis libraries, that take me a long time to resolve.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

I would like to create strong analytic pipelines that can withstand repeat analysis, new data sets, and structured so they can be adapted to new similar, but not exactly the same problems.

Bryan Blue

Graduate student | Biosystems Engineering | bryanblue@arizona.edu

How comfortable are you with the following skills?

Navigate around filesystem using shell commands 3: Perform task with no help
Use git commands such as git add and git push 2: Perform task with some help
Share your code using a GitHub repo 2: Perform task with some help
Organize and name files/folders for a research project 2: Perform task with some help
Use R to clean and reformat dataframes 2: Perform task with some help
Write your own function in R 1: Not able to perform task
Use a for loop in R 1: Not able to perform task
Document text and code/output using RMarkdown 2: Perform task with some help

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

Data analysis for climate and experiment data collected using a data logger from the Tropical Rainforest at Biosphere 2.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

Writing clean R code, and I found that there are not a lot of others that conform to, or know how to, follow the same conventions.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

I am collecting environment data from within Biosphere 2’s tropical rain forest. I will need to use this along with my data logger information to produce a report that will be able to be compared to very limited previous work. The previous work does not share data, calculations, data analysis methods. Ideally, I would like to lay a framework for future work that others could use to take a more standardized approach to these types of experiments. This will allow for a more direct comparison between experiments.

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

Data wrangling, statistical modeling and learning, data visualization, as well as reporting and teaching.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

Git and shell commands may seem a bit arcane for those who have no background in computer science.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

I’ll utilize this knowledge to increase my productivity overall. I’m also interested in quality control and reproducibility, especially when it involves teamwork. My research agenda on causal inference is quite data-intensive, so I must keep honing my data management skill set. As a passionate R educator, I can tell that people are more attracted to the programming arena when they learn that R benefits -e.g., reproducibility- go well beyond mere data crunching.

I’d like to have easily reproducible code on my GitHub account to back up my findings with my metabarcoding journal articles that will be coming out in about a year. I’d also like to just learn best practices, now that I’m finally getting more into coding.

Graduate student | Ecology and Evolutionary Biology | gsfinch@arizona.edu

Write your own function in R 2: Perform task with some help

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

I use R for conducting some analyses, manipulating data and making figures. This often involves plotting annotating phylogenies and data associated with them. I have been experimenting with reformatting data and writing functions in R, but am still very much a beginner at these tasks.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

I just need more structured time and guidance devoted to learning these skills.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

I will be finishing grad school in two years, and I need to get better at coding, organizing my code and analyses, and making them publicly available before I do. I specifically expect to apply these skills to species distribution modelling and biogeography as well as a population genetics project. I would also like to be able to write functions for extracting data from online databases (particularly chromosome counts), cleaning and processing and analyzing the data. Finally, I will be sequencing and analyzing a number of plant genomes (and making associated figures) through a combination of python and R.

Jordan Gunning

Graduate student | Nutritional Sciences | jordangunning@arizona.edu

How comfortable are you with the following skills?

Navigate around filesystem using shell commands 2: Perform task with some help
Use git commands such as git add and git push 2: Perform task with some help
Share your code using a GitHub repo 2: Perform task with some help
Organize and name files/folders for a research project 3: Perform task with no help
Use R to clean and reformat dataframes 3: Perform task with no help
Write your own function in R 3: Perform task with no help
Use a for loop in R 2: Perform task with some help
Document text and code/output using RMarkdown 2: Perform task with some help

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

I use R largely for analyzing bulk and single cell RNA sequencing data. The packages I use most often are Seurat, ggplot2, ggpubr, GSVA, and scGSVA for data analysis and visualization. I look at DEGs, pathway analysis from GSEA, and am wanting to learn things like ligand-receptor analysis and CellChat. I am currently working on a heavily-bioinformatics based immunometabolism project in radiation damaged salivary glands - we are using select GSEA kegg and hallmark pathways to understand how radiation is altering inflammatory and metabolic pathways, how these pathways are changing in specific subpopulations of immune cells, and how this may relate to chronic salivary gland dysfunction.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

One thing that has been difficult to learn is how to manipulate the data into the correct format (data frame vs matrix vs list vs dataset etc) with the appropriate columns/rows in order to do the desired analysis. Another obstacle is that I have little experience with github - I have put so much of my effort into learning R and I haven’t put the same effort into learning github. I know the basics but need to understand it better as I start working on bigger/more collaborative projects. Something I also struggle with is keeping all of my files organized - I use a “project” file in R with data/scripts/output folders but struggle to keep my files as organized as I would like.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

Understanding and implementing version control will help me stay more organized - I tend to save everything and have multiple scripts for each figure/set of figures because I’m scared of losing them. I am also wanting to improve my programming skills - there are some ideas I have for figures (for example: plotting the top 5 different pathways in each cell type following radiation and the top 5 differentially expressed genes in each of these pathways, receptor/ligand analysis, upstream receptor analysis) that I would like to be able to do entirely on my own. I am almost always able to get started and come up with a preliminary idea of what the figure will look like, but I want to be able to fine tune the details and be able to make the exact figure I have in my head. Lastly, I want to understand Rmarkdown better - I am going to start working on a new bioinformatics project in my lab in the next ~6 months and would like to have Rmarkdown files for the code so that others in my lab & collaborators can more easily follow along & add their input. Further, some of my scripts have dozens of # lines in R with notes about what the code does, the data I’m using, and the analysis I’m trying to run - sometimes they get lost in the shuffle and it can be hard to find exactly what I’m looking for. Being able to have the code in an Rmarkdown file would make this less confusing for me and coworkers/collaborators I’m sending the scripts to.

Madeleine deBlois

Research professional | Family and Consumer Sciences | mdeblois@arizona.edu

How comfortable are you with the following skills?

Navigate around filesystem using shell commands 2: Perform task with some help
Use git commands such as git add and git push 1: Not able to perform task
Share your code using a GitHub repo 1: Not able to perform task

Use R to clean and reformat dataframes 2: Perform task with some help
Write your own function in R 3: Perform task with no help
Use a for loop in R 2: Perform task with some help
Document text and code/output using RMarkdown 1: Not able to perform task

What are some common tasks you currently use R for?

Data analysis for evaluation projects that we conduct. There are more proficient R users in our group, so much of my current work in R is amending and updating code that they wrote.

If you’ve tried to learn some of these skills before, what were some obstacles in incorporating them into your research?

Lack of regular use of new skills has led to their atrophy. I default to letting the more proficient coders do the coding. Helpful for efficient work flow, but I would like to make sure that I have the skills to continue that work.

How do you envision applying what you will learn in this workshop series to your on research? Provide specific examples.

The more-expert R users in our group may have future life events that take them away from our group. I’d like to be functional in using (and making necessary updates to) the robust code they’ve written to do things like pull and process census data so that we could continue to do our needs assessments and related work processing secondary data for descriptive use by Cooperative Extension and community partners. Two members of our team took this class last year, so they have been working on making their processes replicable, but if they leave, there is no one currently able to pick up that baton.
